segments.question: Paula, tell me — I need you to tell me where — where were you born?
segments.answer: I was born in a small town named Constance in Germany.

segments.question: What year were you born?
And wha — when you were born, you — today your name is Paula Blue, but what was your given name in —
segments.answer: My name was [indecipherable] Paula Regina Goldlust.

segments.question: Paula, okay.
segments.answer: Yeah, Paula.

segments.question: And in 1928, describe to me — in the later years, when you remember, as early as you remember, what it was like in Constance.
segments.answer: Constance being a smaller town, there was a — a Jewish community, synagogue, Jewish life. Jewish schools, teacher. And the — as I said, our Jewish community was quite active, and the — and the children were at that — at that time, we went to public school, and Hebrew school.

segments.question: Would you say you-your parents were very religious, or moderately religious?
segments.answer: My mother was leaning towards really rel — quite religious. My father was more to a lesser degree. But he kept ko — kept kosher, as far as possib — as far as I remember. segments.answer: What were their names?

segments.question: Their names and their birthdates.
segments.answer: My father, I think was May 30", 1896, and my mother March 24", 1894.

segments.question: Your father’s name was Bernard?
segments.answer: Bernard.

segments.question: And your mother?
segments.answer: Manya.

segments.question: Where were they born?
segments.answer: They were born in Poland.

segments.question: Do you know the towns?
segments.answer: I believe was a small town near Kielce, or something like that.

segments.question: Did they come from large families?
segments.answer: My mother had a — yes, actually, I believe so. And I don’t know, I don’t remember how many brothers and sisters they had. segments.answer: I don’t know —

segments.question: Your father was still considered a Polish citizen after he moved to Germany, or did he —
segments.answer: No, no, he was considered stateless.

segments.question: He was considered stateless, okay. And —
segments.answer: And in Germany, who — whatever the — the head of the household is the whole family considered stateless, takes on the nationality of the husband and the father.

segments.question: What did your father do?
segments.answer: He had a business, a clothing and tailoring.

segments.question: And would you say you were a prominent Jewish family in the community?
segments.answer: Moderately so, yes, we were, yeah. Belonged to — I mean, everybody belonged to the synagogue in the Jewish community, or what they call the gemeindehaus, which was community center.

segments.answer: He — his name — my brother’s name was — was Leo Goldlust, and he was born October 7, 1924.

segments.question: Do you recall early childhood with Leo, being able to roam freely in the streets, do things?
segments.answer: Early on, yes, yeah, yeah. Let’s say until — let’s say 30 — as I recall, °36 - °37, we — not freely. I mean, there was always the fear of — of Nazi. We’d play Juden and so forth and so on. But we went to school in [indecipherable] to public school, he went to public school and I went to public school and they — there were a few Jewish children. There was another Jewish child — girl in my class. Boys and girls went to separate schools, and the — it — it was so-so. I mean, the other children greeted the fuehrer and so forth and so on and we — we were sitting, I mean Jewish — Jew children — Jewish children, we were sitting in the seats, we didn’t get up. Whatever, whatever, the — but the — but otherwise we were mostly together with other Jewish children.

segments.question: When earlier on I asked you about your father leaving Poland.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.answer: I don’t know.

segments.question: Once he was in Germany, did he ever travel back to Poland?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: And did you —
segments.answer: No, he lost Polish citizenship. I think he left across the border illegally, or came to Germany illegally, or left Poland, or whatever. I — I don’t know exactly, but we were stateless, we were not Polish citizens.

segments.question: When you — when we first were talking earlier with your son, he mentioned that Constance is literally on the Swiss border.
segments.answer: It is.

segments.question: You can walk back and forth.
segments.answer: Right, mm-hm.

segments.question: Before the war, do you remember being able to do this? Do you remember people being able to cross the border —
segments.answer: Oh yes. Yes, we did.

segments.answer: Switzerland was closed. I mean, if they didn’t — 1f they wouldn’t — wouldn’t accept Jewish refugees, very, very few. But they immigrate — to immigrate into — to Switzerland was quite impossible, apparently. But we did cross the border, was a — was one — one Jewish community for — at a certain time, but they became — as things became worse in Germany, the — the Jewish community in — in Switzerland [indecipherable] remained — remained by themselves.

segments.question: And they re — they remained intact, but in Constance the —
segments.answer: People started —

segments.question: — people started to flee?
segments.answer: Yeah. People started immigrating to — to United States, to Argentina, to wherever. Where there was any — any opening to go to — to — at that time to Israel, which was Palestine at the time, if they were lucky enough to get there.

segments.question: They took your father with them?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: They arrested him?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Do you know where they took him?
segments.answer: Gestapo headquarters, we — we assumed, and from there to Dachau. The — all — all the Jewish men were taken to — were arrested the same — that same night or morning, early mornings.

segments.question: How long was he in Dachau, do you know?
segments.answer: He came back — I re — I recall he came back Hanukkah time, which must have been about four or six weeks later.

segments.question: So, just to clarify, he was arrested on Kristallnacht, which was November —
segments.answer: Just November 10.

segments.question: — ninth, 10".
segments.answer: Right

segments.answer: Sounds right. And then they started releasing peop — men and — slowly, with the provision that they would leave Germany within, I don’t remember was six weeks, or six months. I’m assuming it was six months because my father left in June of 1939.

segments.question: How did they —
segments.answer: So they had to leave. They had to leave Germany.

segments.question: How did he leave?
segments.answer: He left — there was an opening — England had an opening for the a — as I recall, I — I think I’m correct about it, for men being released from — from the camps, there were other camps, Buchenwald was one of the camps, Sachsenhausen, there were other camps that they took the [indecipherable] men, the Jewish men there. And they — so England opened up for those men that were released, without their families, and the — they — there was a camp, called Kitchener camp in — in England, near London [| presume it was, that housed — housed the men. And the — my father tried, of course, to — the separation was supposed to be brief, but to bring us there, but war broke out in le-less than six months later and that — that was the end of that for us. segments.question: Back up a little bit, and just explain to me. He left in June of 1939, and at that point, had he — had your family tried to get on the quota to go to a different country?
segments.answer: Oh yes, my — actually we had a very eva — to the United States. There was a — which we fell under the Polish quota, where my — my father was born, and it was a very — very — and I believe my father [indecipherable] qui-quite early with the American consulate, which was in Stuttgart, I believe. And the — but — but it was very slow, slow moving. It was a quota, so —

segments.question: So he had applied for —
segments.answer: And we had — we had papers for the — my father’s cousin in New York who sent papers, but American consulate was slow in — in — in giving out papers — visas for families. Many of them — some of them made it, some of them don’t. Many, many did not.

segments.question: So you remained with your mother in and Leo after June of 1939 in Constance.
segments.answer: Right, right.

segments.question: And how was the situation in Constance for you? Were you still going to school?
segments.answer: No. 1938 we — Jewish children couldn’t go to school any more. So also there were pe — many Jewish families had left already, and there were few Jewish This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. segments.question: How did you feel day to day? What was feeling in your household, what was the feeling [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Well, we were very — a — it was rather a desperate situation. W-We couldn’t — we didn’t get any more mail from my — from my father, we were cut off. Did get some mail from — to Switzerland. Somebody smuggled it in, or from — from a neighbor that we wrote to, but we were pretty much cut off.

segments.question: His business gone, taken from him.
segments.answer: Business gone, right, mm-hm.

segments.question: So what were you living on?
segments.answer: I don’t — I —I don’t know. There must have been a — there must have been a — some kind of a thing, because we — we did — I mean, we just existed, I mean, put it this way. My mother and Leo and myself.

So the — the first — that was the first deportation from Germany, actual —

segments.question: Can you translate what you mean?
segments.answer: To make it free of Jews.

segments.question: When you were gathering things, because you were forced to leave, your mother and you and Leo, what did you do at the house, what —
segments.answer: We — oh, we lived already three families in one, Jews had to start living into one area, on one street. Anyhow, I suppose that was the — the plan to — to make it easier, I suppose. And we lived in — with another — with other three families in one large apartment, which I walked in, by the way, in May, when we were in Constance, which was pretty — quite traumatic, actually. segments.question: Describe your experiences when you first arrived.
segments.answer: We were taken from the train, as I recall. We were taken from the trains onto camion — trucks. And the — we were pretty — from — from the same community, actually, we were together. And the — that was long way. I believe the Germans probably had an — had a — had — they don’t need the consent, but they — Vichy, France accepted, or had to accept the Jewish refugees from there. I don’t remember how many there were from the whole area [indecipherable] from larger cities. And there were quite a few — quite a few children actually there. In Constance there were not too many children, there was just Leo, myself and Hootie(ph) and another child was there actually, or teenager, in this — left in the city of Constance.

segments.question: So you — it took days to get to Camp de Gurs?
segments.answer: We — I-I don’t remem — probably two or three days, something like that, because we stopped, I think. As I learned later on, there was — we didn’t — Vichy, France didn’t want to accept us, and they — the Germans, you know, tried to — I mean Vichy didn’t have much chance there.
